channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Why is President Trump calling suspected smugglers 'unlawful combatants'?
item.description: Scott Anderson, a former U.S. diplomat and Brookings Institution fellow, breaks down how a term from the George W. Bush administration is influencing U.S. actions at sea.
item.content:encoded: Scott Anderson, a former U.S. diplomat and Brookings Institution fellow, breaks down how a term from the George W. Bush administration is influencing U.S. actions at sea.
item.dc:creator: Sacha Pfeiffer

item.title: Amid settler attacks, Palestinians are trying to save their traditional olive and date harvests
item.description: The Palestinian tradition of olive picking and dates harvest in the occupied West Bank is under threat from Israeli settlers who have increased their attacks on farmers this season.
item.content:encoded: The Palestinian tradition of olive picking and dates harvest in the occupied West Bank is under threat from Israeli settlers who have increased their attacks on farmers this season.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: Are movie theaters worth it anymore?
item.description: NPR's Bob Mondello and Marc Rivers discuss why movie theaters still matter in the streaming age and what continues to draw audiences to the big screen
item.content:encoded: NPR's Bob Mondello and Marc Rivers discuss why movie theaters still matter in the streaming age and what continues to draw audiences to the big screen
item.dc:creator: Bob Mondello

item.title: Both parties under pressure to reopen government as food benefits stop and health premiums soar
item.description: The shutdown's suspension of food aid and rising healthcare costs is putting new pressure on both parties to break the stalemate in Washington
item.content:encoded: The shutdown's suspension of food aid and rising healthcare costs is putting new pressure on both parties to break the stalemate in Washington
item.dc:creator: Barbara Sprunt

item.title: In her memoir, Margaret Atwood reveals how she found source material and love
item.description: For years, the author of The Handmaid's Tale, The Blind Assassin and Cat's Eye was reluctant to write a memoir, but in 'Book of Lives: A Memoir', Margaret Atwood talks about being Canadian, and the people and places that shaped her writing.
item.content:encoded: For years, the author of The Handmaid's Tale, The Blind Assassin and Cat's Eye was reluctant to write a memoir, but in 'Book of Lives: A Memoir', Margaret Atwood talks about being Canadian, and the people and places that shaped her writing.
item.dc:creator: Sacha Pfeiffer

item.title: Trump is leaning into his crackdown on city crime. The GOP sees it as a winning issue
item.description: While previous deployments to Democratic-led cities have largely led to protests and lawsuits, Trump is banking on the moves helping him and Republicans, especially in next year's midterms.
item.content:encoded:
While previous deployments to Democratic-led cities have largely led to protests and lawsuits, Trump is banking on the moves helping him and Republicans, especially in next year's midterms.

(Image credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds)
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordo√±ez

item.title: Hidden passage of emperors opened at the Colosseum
item.description: Visitors to the Colosseum in Rome can now walk through a tunnel that even in Roman times was exclusively reserved for emperors
item.content:encoded: Visitors to the Colosseum in Rome can now walk through a tunnel that even in Roman times was exclusively reserved for emperors
item.dc:creator: Ruth Sherlock

item.title: Author of 'The Second Estate' argues that America's tax code has created a new aristocracy
item.description: In her book The Second Estate, Ray Madoff explains how the U.S. tax system lets the ultra-rich grow their wealth tax-free while working Americans bear the burden.
item.content:encoded: In her book The Second Estate, Ray Madoff explains how the U.S. tax system lets the ultra-rich grow their wealth tax-free while working Americans bear the burden.
item.dc:creator: Sacha Pfeiffer

item.title: How the time change could help teens rest
item.description: The switch to standard time offers sleep-deprived teenagers a rare chance to catch up on much-needed rest.
item.content:encoded: The switch to standard time offers sleep-deprived teenagers a rare chance to catch up on much-needed rest.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Boden

item.title: How NPR reporters turn newspaper stories into sound
item.description: NPR's Laura Sullivan, Frank Langfitt and Sacha Pfeiffer reflect on how writing for radio differs from their days in newspapers, and what it takes to make stories come alive through sound.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Laura Sullivan, Frank Langfitt and Sacha Pfeiffer reflect on how writing for radio differs from their days in newspapers, and what it takes to make stories come alive through sound.
item.dc:creator: Sacha Pfeiffer
